articles.headline: Fed Forecasts Faster Growth as Economy Improves
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve called for growth of 3.4 percent to 3.9 percent this year, up from 3 percent to 3.6 percent.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve called for growth of 3.4 percent to 3.9 percent this year, up from 3 percent to 3.6 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve disclosed on Wednesday that policy makers had substantially upgraded their forecasts for how much the economy will grow this year, though they expect unemployment to remain painfully high for some time.

articles.headline: House Votes to End Alternate Jet Engine Program
articles.snippet: Killing the engine would cut an additional $450 million in this year’s spending bill and save up to $3 billion over the next several years.
articles.abstract: Killing the engine would cut an additional $450 million in this year’s spending bill and save up to $3 billion over the next several years.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a sign that more than half the Republican freshmen are willing to cut military spending, the House voted 233 to 198 on Wednesday to cancel an alternate fighter jet engine that the Bush and Obama administrations had tried to kill for the last five years.

articles.headline: A Phone That’s the Life of a Laptop
articles.snippet: The Atrix 4G phone from Motorola provides the brains for a laptop. It’s ingenious, fast and superbly designed. But nothing is perfect.
articles.abstract: The Atrix 4G phone from Motorola provides the brains for a laptop. It’s ingenious, fast and superbly designed. But nothing is perfect.
articles.lead_paragraph: Does the redundancy of your gadgets ever bother you?

articles.headline: As U.S. Agencies Put More Value on a Life, Businesses Fret
articles.snippet: Agencies that calculate the worth of a life have been raising the number, which affects how much the government should spend to prevent a single death.
articles.abstract: Agencies that calculate the worth of a life have been raising the number, which affects how much the government should spend to prevent a single death.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As the players here remake the nation’s vast regulatory system, they have been grappling with a subject that is more the province of poets and philosophers than bureaucrats: what is the value of a human life?

articles.headline: Borders’ Bankruptcy Shakes Industry
articles.snippet: Publishers mourned the loss of valuable shelf space as Borders filed for bankruptcy, and they questioned whether the company’s deep-rooted problems could be overcome.
articles.abstract: Publishers mourned the loss of valuable shelf space as Borders filed for bankruptcy, and they questioned whether the company’s deep-rooted problems could be overcome.
articles.lead_paragraph: After Borders, the 40-year-old retail chain that helped define the age of the book superstore, filed for bankruptcy protection on Wednesday, the struggling book industry was left wondering what was next  and maybe even who was next.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Staying in Touch With Home, for Better or Worse
articles.snippet: The communication gap that once kept troops from staying looped into the details of home life has all but disappeared. But there are drawbacks to the connectedness.
articles.abstract: The communication gap that once kept troops from staying looped into the details of home life has all but disappeared. But there are drawbacks to the connectedness.
articles.lead_paragraph: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan — Forget the drones, laser-guided bombs and eye-popping satellite imagery. For the average soldier, the most significant change to modern warfare might just boil down to instant chatting.

articles.headline: Unrest Spreads, Some Violently, in Middle East
articles.snippet: Governments appeared to flounder on just how to outrun mostly peaceful movements spreading through the Mideast.
articles.abstract: Governments appeared to flounder on just how to outrun mostly peaceful movements spreading through the Mideast.
articles.lead_paragraph: From northern Africa to the Persian Gulf, governments appeared to flounder over just how to outrun mostly peaceful movements, spreading erratically like lava erupting from a volcano, with no predictable end.

articles.headline: Shy U.S. Intellectual Created Playbook Used in a Revolution
articles.snippet: For decades, the writings of Gene Sharp have inspired dissidents around the world.
articles.abstract: For decades, the writings of Gene Sharp have inspired dissidents around the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Halfway around the world from Tahrir Square in Cairo, an aging American intellectual shuffles about his cluttered brick row house in a working-class neighborhood here. His name is Gene Sharp. Stoop-shouldered and white-haired at 83, he grows orchids, has yet to master the Internet and hardly seems like a dangerous man.

articles.headline: Bahrain Turmoil Poses Fresh Test for White House
articles.snippet: A brutal crackdown on protesters in Bahrain killed at least five people, creating another diplomatic challenge for the Obama administration.
articles.abstract: A brutal crackdown on protesters in Bahrain killed at least five people, creating another diplomatic challenge for the Obama administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANAMA, Bahrain  A brutal government crackdown on pro-democracy protesters here on Thursday not only killed at least five people but, once again, placed the Obama administration in the uncomfortable position of dealing with a strategic Arab ally locked in a showdown with its people.
articles.byline: By Michael Slackman and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Fervent G.O.P. Freshmen Ignite Budget Fight
articles.snippet: The 87 new Republican House members have brought party leaders some embarrassing defeats.
articles.abstract: The 87 new Republican House members have brought party leaders some embarrassing defeats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The last speaker was Representative Steve Southerland, freshman lawmaker from Florida, and so he dug deep.
